Authors

What is the substance of adaptation projects?

Subtitle

‘Climate adaption’ is a vague notion and for at least five reasons.

A) The effects of global warming are expected to touch all aspects of collective life and in particular:

o   Social systems (transport, industry, energy production, urban & rural settlements…)

o   Natural systems (environment & biodiversity conservation, water cycles…)

o   Mixed (land use, agriculture & food security, health, landscape and tourism…)

B) Adaptation initiative can follow several different approaches:

o   Adaptation can be reactive (when it copes with an immediately perceived risk) or anticipatory (when it is meant to reduce a long-term vulnerability).

o   It can reduce vulnerability (when it tries to diminish the exposure to climate transformation) or increase the resilience (when it targets the capacity to handle the changes).

o   It can be incremental (if it aims to conserve the current state of affairs) or transformational (if it intends to radically change social systems).

C) Adaptation can be initiated and take place at different levels, varying in a continuum that goes

o   from local, community-based, bottom-up initiatives;

o   to national, institutional, top-down initiative.

D) Adaptation projects can occurs at different geographical (large or small), temporal (long-term or short-term) and financial scales.

E) Finally adaptation can be financed by different sources:

o   the national government

o   the bi-lateral aid (often as a part of the wider development aid)

o   the multi-lateral funds specifically dedicated to climate change

o   the private sector and in particular the insurances

EMAPS can contribute to the definition of the notion of ‘climate change adaptation’ by identifying and highlighting in which areas of these different spectrums the actual adaptation actions tend to be located.

To do so EMAPS has so far investigated 5 main sets of data.

1.     Two databases of public adaptation projects: UNDP adaptation learning mechanism (http://www.undp-alm.org/) and Ci-Grasp (http://www.pik-potsdam.de/~wrobel/ci_2/). Maps 7, 8, 9, 2

2.     Two databases of private adaptation projects: UNFCCC Private Sector Initiative (http://unfccc.int/adaptation/workstreams/nairobi_work_programme/items/6547.php) and ClimateWise on insurance industry (http://www.climatewise.org.uk/). Map 2

3.     The multi-lateral funding (according to the data collected by the website http://www.climatefundsupdate.org/). Map 22

4.     The bi-lateral funding (as captured by the OECD statistics http://www.oecd.org/investment/stats/officialdevelopmentassistancedefinitionandcoverage.htm). Map 22

5.     The NAPAs (National Adaptation Programs of Action) compiled by the least developed countries in order to indicate their intentions in terms of adaptation (http://unfccc.int/adaptation/workstreams/national_adaptation_programmes_of_action/items/4583.php). Map 22

Unfortunately the richness and the formalization of these different data sources are very diverse (varying from the extreme details of the Ci-Grasp data to the very unstructured information of the NAPAS). This suggests that we maintain and re-design the different maps visualizing the specific information present in each database. In particular, efforts should be placed in visualizing the richest datasets.

However some basic information seems to be available in all databases, in particular:

o   The country in which the project takes place.

o   The amount of money invested.

o   The sector concerned

o   The year(s) in which the project takes place

Drawing on this information, we can in Milan build a cross-dataset visualization comparing

o   The number of projects

o   The amount of the funding

o   The sector of adaptation

o   The source of funding

Across different:

1.     Countries (to identify which countries that have been more active in adaption and to profile countries according to the adaptation sectors that they target and the type of funding that they attract).

2.     Periods of time (to identify if adaptation has changed through time in terms of countries, size of projects, source of funding).

3.     Funding source (to detect if different funding mechanism are more active on specific countries, sectors, or size of project).

4.     Sector of adaptation (to characterized different sectors in terms of the area of the world, the project size and the source of funding).

The ultimate research objective of this multi-maps narrative might be to illustrate how there is not such a thing as a climate change adaptation, but rather a several types of adaption well characterized according to different parameters.
